questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents with a history of recurrent bacterial infections. Laboratory investigations reveal defects in the innate immune system. The physician explains to the patient the role of a group of receptors crucial in the innate immune response. Which of the following is a correct statement about these receptors, known as toll-like receptors?

options.label: A
options.text: They are antigen-specific receptors found on B cells.

options.label: B
options.text: They act by inducing cytokine release upon recognition of pathogen-associated molecular patterns.

options.label: C
options.text: They are part of the adaptive immune system.

options.label: D
options.text: They facilitate microbial invasion into host cells.

questions.correct_answer: B. They act by inducing cytokine release upon recognition of pathogen-associated molecular patterns.
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) They act by inducing cytokine release upon recognition of pathogen-associated molecular patterns.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A . TLRs are not antigen-specific ; they recognize patterns rather than specific antigens.
  • • Option A
  • • TLRs are not antigen-specific
  • • Option C . TLRs are a component of the innate immune system , not the adaptive immune system.
  • • Option C
  • • TLRs are a component of the innate immune system
  • • Option D . TLRs do not facilitate microbial invasion ; they play a role in pathogen recognition and initiating an immune response .
  • • Option D
  • • TLRs do not facilitate microbial invasion
  • • pathogen recognition
  • • initiating an immune response

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Toll-like receptors (TLRs) trigger cytokine release by recognizing pathogen-associated molecular patterns , highlighting their role in innate immunity. TLRs are not antigen-specific but instead identify general patterns to activate transcription factors , leading to cytokine production and various antimicrobial activities.
  • ➤ Toll-like receptors
  • ➤ trigger cytokine
  • ➤ pathogen-associated molecular patterns
  • ➤ role in innate immunity. TLRs are not antigen-specific
  • ➤ general patterns to activate transcription factors
  • ➤ cytokine production
  • ➤ antimicrobial activities.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man with a history of diabetes and chronic kidney disease presents to the emergency department with fever, hypotension, and a raised white cell count. His skin is warm and flushed, but there is no rash, desquamation, or signs of localized infection. Blood cultures are pending. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis if this patient's condition is not primarily due to a toxin-mediated effect?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Septic shock

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A: Toxic shock syndrome is characterized by fever, rash, desquamation , and hypotension , often associated with tampon use or skin infections but is toxin-mediated , which does not fit the clinical scenario provided.
  • • Option A:
  • • Toxic shock syndrome
  • • fever, rash, desquamation
  • • hypotension
  • • tampon use or skin infections
  • • toxin-mediated
  • • Option B: Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome is a toxin-mediated condition that presents with widespread blistering and desquamation of the skin , especially in infants and children .
  • • Option B:
  • • Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome
  • • toxin-mediated
  • • presents with widespread blistering
  • • desquamation of the skin
  • • infants and children
  • • Option C: Staphylococcal food poisoning is also toxin-mediated and would present with rapid onset nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea following ingestion of contaminated food.
  • • Option C:
  • • Staphylococcal food poisoning
  • • toxin-mediated
  • • rapid onset nausea, vomiting,
  • • diarrhea

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The patient's presentation of fever, hypotension, raised white cell count , and absence of rash or localized infection signs , especially in the context of his pre-existing conditions (diabetes and chronic kidney disease), strongly suggests septic shock . Septic shock is a severe infection that leads to organ dysfunction and low blood pressure , not necessarily linked to a toxin-mediated effect like those seen in toxic shock syndrome or staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome .
  • ➤ fever, hypotension, raised white cell count
  • ➤ absence of rash or localized infection signs
  • ➤ pre-existing conditions
  • ➤ septic shock
  • ➤ Septic shock
  • ➤ severe infection
  • ➤ organ dysfunction
  • ➤ low blood pressure
  • ➤ toxin-mediated effect
  • ➤ toxic shock syndrome
  • ➤ staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome
  • ➤ Ref: Apurva Sastry Essentials of Medical Microbiology Essentials of Medical Microbiology pg 514/4e
  • ➤ Ref: Apurva Sastry Essentials of Medical Microbiology Essentials of Medical Microbiology pg 514/4e

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman brings her 3-year-old son to the clinic. She is concerned about food safety and asks about the best method to ensure the milk she gives to her child is free from harmful bacteria. As part of your explanation about the pasteurization process, you informed her about the standard temperature and time required to pasteurize milk effectively. Which of the following is the correct combination of temperature and time for the pasteurization of milk?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) 63°C for 30 min

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A . 73°C for 20 min - This combination of temperature and time is excessive for pasteurization and could lead to changes in the nutritional quality and flavor of the milk.
  • • Option A
  • • 73°C for 20 min -
  • • temperature and time is excessive for pasteurization
  • • changes in the nutritional quality and flavor of the milk.
  • • Option B . 63°C for 20 min - This temperature is correct for pasteurization, but the duration is too long , which can lead to alterations in the milk's properties.
  • • Option B
  • • 63°C for 20 min
  • • correct for pasteurization, but the duration is too long
  • • Option C . 73°C for 30 secs - This temperature is higher than necessary for effective pasteurization and can cause unnecessary changes to the milk.
  • • Option C
  • • 73°C for 30 secs -
  • • higher than necessary for effective pasteurization

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pasteurization of milk is a process used to kill harmful bacteria without significantly changing the milk's nutritional value or flavor. Two methods are used for pasteurization of milk , the Holder method with a temperature of 63°C for 30 min or Flash method (72°C for 20 sec) followed by rapid cooling to 13°C. This method is effective in killing most bacteria and pathogens found in milk while preserving its quality. All non-spring pathogens are killed except Coxiella which survives Holder’s method
  • ➤ Pasteurization

questions.text: Farmer with traumatic ulcer in eye and septate hyphae seen. Causative organism is ? ( FMGE July 2023)
questions.explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Farmers often suffer from injuries involving organic matter. The presence of a traumatic ulcer in the eye coupled with the identification of septate hyphae points toward a fungal infection.
  • • Between Mucor and Aspergillus, the distinguishing factor is the type of hyphae. Aspergillus forms septate hyphae, meaning the hyphae have regular, cross-wall divisions. In contrast, Mucor forms aseptate (or coenocytic) hyphae, which lack these septa.

  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Mucor: Although Mucor is a fungus that can cause infections, it forms aseptate hyphae. This characteristic helps differentiate it from Aspergillus in cases of fungal eye infections.
  • • Option A. Mucor:
  • • Option C. Streptococcus pyogenes: This bacterium can cause various infections, including those in the eye, but it does not form hyphae. Thus, it cannot be the causative organism in this scenario.
  • • Option C. Streptococcus pyogenes:
  • • Option D. Pseudomonas: This is another bacterium that can cause eye infections, particularly in the context of contact lens wearers, but like Streptococcus pyogenes, it does not form hyphae.
  • • Option D. Pseudomonas:

questions.text: A patient presents with pain in the genital area and a painful vesicle on examination, accompanied by painful lymphadenopathy. What is the diagnosis? (INICET NOV 2023)

  • • Other Options
  • • Option B. Molluscum: Molluscum contagiosum causes painless, pearly papules, which are typically umbilicated. These lesions are not vesicular and do not cause painful lymphadenopathy.

  • • Option C. HPV: Human Papillomavirus infection results in the formation of warts, which are generally painless. HPV warts can appear on the genital area but do not present with vesicles or painful lymphadenopathy.

  • • Option D. HIV: Human Immunodeficiency Virus does not present with genital vesicles. HIV infection leads to systemic symptoms such as fever, weight loss, and generalized lymphadenopathy, rather than localized painful vesicles in the genital area.

  • • HIV:

questions.text: A 35-year-old HIV positive patient presents with mucosal lesions in the mouth as shown in the image below. On microscopy, budding yeasts and pseudohyphae are seen. What is the likely diagnosis? ( NEET PG 2020)

questions.text: A patient from Uttar Pradesh presented with fever, pallor, and hepatosplenomegaly. Peripheral smear examination showed pancytopenia. Buffy coat examination showed macrophages laden with organisms with a kinetoplast. What is the vector for the likely disease? (NEET PG 2021)

Recognizing its epidemiology, clinical presentation, and diagnostic features is crucial for prompt diagnosis and treatment. Awareness and control of the vector, along with appropriate medical intervention, are essential in areas endemic for this disease.

questions.text: A photographer who recently returned from Africa presents to the emergency department with abdominal pain, hepatomegaly, and hemorrhagic manifestations. questions.text: In emergency situations where there is no time for blood cross-matching, Fresh Frozen Plasma (FFP) transfusion decisions are based on the universal donor concept. However, unlike red blood cells, the universal donor for plasma is based on the AB blood group, not the O blood group. This is because plasma contains antibodies, and the AB blood group is considered the universal plasma donor since it doesn't contain anti-A or anti-B antibodies. Therefore, the safest option for transfusing FFP in a trauma patient without cross-matching would be:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) AB Rh D –

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. O Rh D +: O group plasma contains both anti-A and anti-B antibodies , which can cause reactions in recipients with A, B, or AB blood types.
  • • Option A. O Rh D +:
  • • O group plasma
  • • both anti-A and anti-B antibodies
  • • reactions in recipients with A, B, or AB blood types.
  • • Option B. O Rh D –: Although Rh negative is preferable , O group plasma is still not ideal due to the presence of anti-A and anti-B antibodies.
  • • Option B. O Rh D
  • • Rh negative is preferable
  • • O group plasma
  • • Option C. AB Rh D +: While AB plasma is suitable due to lack of anti-A and anti-B antibodies , Rh positive plasma could cause problems for Rh negative recipients.
  • • Option C. AB Rh D
  • • AB plasma is suitable due to lack of anti-A and anti-B antibodies

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Universal donor : Individuals with ‘O’ Rh D negative blood group are called as universal donors because they do not possess either A or B antigen or Rh antigen ; hence, they are generally safe. The anti-A and anti-B antibodies in the transfused O blood group are diluted in recipient’s serum, do not ordinarily cause any damage to the red cells of the A or B blood group recipients.
  • ➤ Universal donor
  • ➤ ‘O’ Rh D negative blood group are called as universal donors
  • ➤ not possess either A or B antigen or Rh antigen
  • ➤ generally safe.
  • ➤ Universal recipients : Individuals with AB Rh D positive blood group do not have both A and B antibodies or Rh D antibodies in serum ; therefore, they can receive any other blood group. Hence, they are called universal recipients.
  • ➤ Universal recipients
  • ➤ AB Rh D positive blood group do not have both A and B antibodies or Rh D antibodies in serum
  • ➤ Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Med. Microbiology 2/e p214
  • ➤ Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Med. Microbiology 2/e p214

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents to the emergency department with a sudden onset of fever, dyspnea, and a non-productive cough. He recently attended a crowded international conference. Chest X-ray reveals a widened mediastinum and bilateral infiltrates. The patient rapidly progresses to severe respiratory distress. A history of similar cases among other conference attendees is reported. Which of the following agents is most likely responsible for this patient's symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Bacillus anthracis (Anthrax)

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B. Variola major (Smallpox) - Typically presents with fever and a characteristic rash , not primarily with respiratory symptoms.
  • • Option B. Variola major (Smallpox)
  • • fever and a characteristic rash
  • • Option C. Yersinia pestis (Plague) - While it can cause pneumonic plague , it is less likely in this scenario given the rapid progression and specific radiological findings.
  • • Option C. Yersinia pestis (Plague)
  • • cause pneumonic plague
  • • less likely
  • • Option D. Francisella tularensis (Tularemia) - Can cause pneumonic tularemia but is less likely than anthrax to present with a widened mediastinum and rapid progression in a bioterrorism scenario.
  • • Option D. Francisella tularensis (Tularemia)
  • • cause pneumonic tularemia
  • • less likely

questions.text: Identify the image shown below? (FMGE AUGUST 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Trichuris trichiura eggs

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Trichuris trichiura eggs are identified by their barrel shape, thick shell, and polar plugs. They are unembryonated when passed in stool and are associated with iron deficiency anemia and rectal prolapse.

questions.text: A male patient presented with bloody diarrhea. On Investigation of stool sample, the organism was found to be gram negative, non-motile and oxidase negative. What could be the cause? (FMGE DECEMBER 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Shigella

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Shigella is a gram-negative, non-motile, and oxidase-negative bacterium that is a common cause of bacillary dysentery, presenting with bloody diarrhea and several potential severe complications.

questions.text: A patient presents with pain abdomen, diarrhea, and a stepladder pattern fever. He also complains of a headache and malaise. His symptoms were gradually worsening over the past 2 weeks. Which of the following is the best diagnostic method? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Widal test

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: An El Tor vibrio was identified to be the causative agent of a diarrhea epidemic. Which of the following is not a characteristic feature of this organism? (FMGE DECEMBER 2021)

options.label: A
options.text: Resistant to El Tor phage V

options.label: D
options.text: Not susceptible to group IV phage

questions.correct_answer: A. Resistant to El Tor phage V
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Resistant to El Tor phage V

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ El Tor vibrios are characterized by their susceptibility to El Tor phage V, intrinsic resistance to polymyxin B, positive Voges-Proskauer test, and non-susceptibility to group IV phage.

questions.text: Rh-ve mother had Rh+ve child. This Rh incompatibility is which type of hypersensitivity reaction? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Cytotoxic

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Rh incompatibility, where an Rh-negative mother has an Rh-positive child, is an example of Type II (cytotoxic) hypersensitivity reaction, where antibodies produced by the mother attack the fetal red blood cells.

questions.text: A child who is regularly eating outside is presenting with icterus and diarrhea, which of the following infectious agent can spread through the Feco-oral route? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Hepatitis A

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hepatitis A and Hepatitis E spread through the Feco-oral route
  • ➤ Feco-oral route
  • ➤ Transmission of Hepatitis B, C, and D can occur sexually

questions.text: Bacillus anthracis is which category of bioweapon? ( FMGE July 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Category A

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Bacillus anthracis is classified as a Category A bioweapon due to its high potential for causing significant public health impact through easy dissemination and high mortality rates.

questions.text: A patient came with meningitis. His protein level was elevated and glucose level was normal. CSF examination showed lymphocytosis. What is the likely etiology? (FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In a patient with meningitis, the presence of lymphocytosis (elevated lymphocytes) in the CSF, along with an elevated protein level and normal glucose level, strongly suggests tuberculous meningitis caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis.

questions.text: A person who has undergone a bone marrow transplant in the past is now presenting with a lung lesion. Upon microscopic analysis, the image of the lesion is provided below. What is the probable responsible organism for this condition? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Mucormycosis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Mucormycosis is indicated in this clinical scenario due to the patient's history of a bone marrow transplant and the presence of a lung lesion. The image provided shows broad aseptate hyphae , which is characteristic of Mucormycosis.

  • • Option A.

  • • Option B.
  • • Cryptococcus:
  • • Option D . Aspergillosis: Shows narrow, acute angled branching and septate, differing from the non-septate hyphae
  • • Option D

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Mucormycosis is characterized broad aseptate hyphae with acute -angle branching. which commonly affecting in immunocompromised patients.

questions.text: Mw vaccine is extracted from which of the following bacteria? (INICET MAY 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) M. indicus pranii

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Mw vaccine is extracted from Mycobacterium indicus pranii and is used in the immunotherapy of leprosy, enhancing immune responses and promoting rapid bacterial clearance.

questions.text: Pneumonia caused by a gram-negative pleomorphic bacillus growing on chocolate agar which is catalase and oxidase-positive. Identify the microorganism. ( INICET MAY 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Haemophilus influenzae

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Haemophilus influenzae is a gram-negative pleomorphic bacillus that grows on chocolate agar and is catalase and oxidase-positive. It is a common cause of respiratory infections, including pneumonia, particularly in young children.
  • ➤ Additional Information
  • ➤ Additional Information

questions.text: Identify the organism from the lifecycle shown in the image given below? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Toxoplasma gondii

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Toxoplasma gondii is an obligate intracellular parasite with a complex lifecycle involving cats as definitive hosts and various animals, including humans, as intermediate hosts. The lifecycle stages, including oocysts and tissue cysts, are crucial for transmission and infection.

questions.text: A patient was sputum negative for tuberculosis, but chest X-ray was suggestive of tuberculosis. Which is the next step according to RNTCP? (INICET NOV 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) CBNAAT

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For patients with negative sputum smears but chest X-ray findings suggestive of TB, CBNAAT is the recommended next diagnostic step under RNTCP guidelines.

questions.text: A patient presents with cervical lymphadenopathy and is found to be retropositive. A fungal culture depicts a velvety growth with red diffusible pigment on the underside, as shown below. Which is the most likely causative organism? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Talaromyces marneffei

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Recognition of the red diffusible pigment in culture is critical in identifying Talaromyces marneffei infection, particularly in HIV-positive patients. It's important to consider this pathogen when patients from endemic regions present with systemic symptoms and lymphadenopathy. Treatment involves antifungal therapy tailored to the severity of the infection, with agents such as itraconazole for mild cases and amphotericin B for severe cases.
